title: Author Beasley’s debut novel is inventive and imaginative
text:
Image 1 of / 1 1 Author Beasley’s debut novel is inventive and imaginative 1 / 1 Back to Gallery In Cassie Beasley’s young adult novel “Circus Mirandus,” Ephraim Tuttle had an inexplicable experience as a child — inexplicable, that is, to adults and other less-than-imaginative persons.
Missing his soldier father, he was wandering a beach one day when he heard music — the kind that one follows on faith that it will lead somewhere.
He arrived at the Circus Mirandus, a 2,500-year-old safe haven for magic, a place where a few individuals have been laboring to keep faith in magic alive, lest it die out entirely for lack of belief.
Actually, this is an old theme in literature. Think of Yeats’ “The Stolen Child,” which warns that magic in the real world is vanishing, “for the world’s more full of weeping than you can understand.” A more familiar example is the resurrection-by-applause of Tinkerbell in every performance of “Peter Pan.”
More Information CIRCUS MIRANDUS
By Cassie Beasley
ISBN 978-0-52542843-5
Dial Books, 304 pages, $17.99
When the book begins, Ephraim is a very old man raising a fifth-grader grandchild, Micah.
Micah knows every detail — he thinks — of the story of his grandfather’s encounter with magic. The central fact of that encounter is that, before Ephraim’s allotted time with the circus was over, a mind-bending illusionist magician named the Lightbender promised him “a miracle.”
But Ephraim never redeemed the pledged miracle and now he is dying.
Circus Mirandus wanders the globe, mostly invisible to mortal eyes, or at least to eyes that cannot see with true innocence.
But need can do wonders, and a portal opens to allow a messenger through, an intelligent parrot, Chintzy, who memorizes Ephraim’s letter and parrots it back to the Lightbender, who happens to be in Bolivia at the time.
The letter is a summons — the time to provide the miracle is now.
Enter Ephraim’s estranged sister, Gertrudis. She not only does not believe Ephraim’s stories, she absolutely hates magic, and tries to separate Micah from his beloved grandfather, even as he is dying. Gertrudis is thoroughly modern and cruel to boot.
Enter Micah’s fifth-grade classmate, Jenny Mendoza . She has a factual, scientific mind. She believes in Micah, but finds his stories irrational.
But magic manifests itself, once it enters a family, in small ways that often go unnoticed even by the gifted individual. Micah’s gift is an ability with knots. For a school project, he ties knots that resemble the alphabet.
In so doing, he — and Jenny — realize that he can tie knots that resemble individuals, but that also can connect them in some way that cannot be explained. Simple magic, but more powerful than either of them know.
There is a similarity between “Circus Mirandus” and Patrick Cauvin ’s 1979 novel “A Little Romance,” in that two pre-teens seek a faith-in-magic solution to a real life situation.
Except that here there is no actual romance, just a pure and innocent desire to believe in another person’s vision of reality. Nevertheless, the bond between Jenny and Micah is one that may transcend time.
This novel for middle-grade readers, the author’s first, is full of hijinks, humorous characters and embarrassing school situations, not to mention wicked great-aunts, but these are beautifully blended with nuanced issues of the human heart — friendship, faith, and loss.
The writing is literate, the characters endearing, the plot inventive, the conception memorable. Applause.
Bryce Milligan is the author of a dozen books for children and adults. He is the publisher/editor of Wings Press , now celebrating its 40th year. Reach him at milligan@wingspress.com.
